Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2009 05:56PM seaofhope wrote: CBM, I had a large node also.  It was 2.7 cm, under my armpit, extracapsular - much bigger than any of the tumors in my breast.  I don't know what the size of the node has to do with diagnosis, do you?  Also had 2 other positive nodes, though much smaller.
Posts.Title: Large amount of nodes removed and positive. michele54 London-Virginia

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2009 11:43AM seaofhope wrote: The waiting is the hardest part.  I feel like I am on automatic pilot, though focused and centered.   The only nervewracking part is not knowing exactly what I have.  Here are my results of the biopsies: 1.auxillary tail - positive for malignant cells.  Consistent with lymph node involved by metastatic adenocarcinoma.  Is this something that is always written if the lymph node tests positive?  2. mass - infiltrating ductal carcinoma, moderately differentiated, no definite ductal carcinoma in situ identified. 3. retroareolar - single focus of infiltrating ductal carcinoma, moderately differentiated, approximately 1mm in greatest dimension.  No ductal carcinoma in situ. 4. Upper outer quadrant - ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), intermediate nuclear grade with apocrine features, involving dednosis, with focal microcalcifications.  No definite stromal invasion identified.  Fibrocystic change. Adenosis. Some of this is self explanatory.  The other is mumbo-jumbo.  I am sure by the end of this I will be an expert on the lingo! I would appreciate any help with this as I await the surgeons's consultation.  Thanks!
Posts.Title: When do I cry? seaofhope one-L

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2009 06:09PM seaofhope wrote: Thanks for all your words of wisdom.  To all who are newly diagnosed or have been going through this for some time - you are in my thoughts and prayers.  Everyone's courage is an inspiration to me.
Posts.Title: When do I cry? seaofhope one-L

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2009 02:07PM seaofhope wrote: I am so happy the radiologist told me.  She got the fine needle biopsy results while I was there.  Also, she is a specialized doctor and probably knows more about breast cancer than other kinds of doctors, with the exception of oncologists and some surgeons.  She must have seen something bad, and this was a breast center.  I am thankful that I did not have to wait all weekend with the uncertainty of it all.  Thanks for all your kind words.  Let the fight begin!
Posts.Title: When do I cry? seaofhope one-L

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2009 10:59AM seaofhope wrote: I think my mind deals with stress in strange ways.  I had an MRI yesterday and had a full blown panic attack - hyperventilating, sweating bullets, etc.  But I stayed in the machine because I knew I would have to do it again anyway.  The physician's assistant held my hands throughout the whole procedure.  I think God sends us angels along the way.  I want to pick her up a gift card to a manicure/pedicure for going above and beyond.
Posts.Title: When do I cry? seaofhope one-L

Posts.Content: seaofhope wrote: I felt a lump a few weeks ago on the side of my breast.  I also felt another small one on the bottom.  The physician assistant said they were moveable and hopefully were cysts. After waiting a month for the mamo and sono, I went for my appointment on Thursday.  After the sonogram the radiologist asked if I am the type of person who wants to know everything upfront.  She said I have advanced cancer.  I can't believe she could tell from only seeing the pictures.  Anyway, I stayed there all day, having a stero core biopsy on 3 spots, and a fine needle biopsy on the lump I felt (which was really a lymph node). She got immediate results on the fine needle and it showed cancer in the lymph node.  The actual breast cancer I really couldn''t feel because it is flat against my chest and goes into the nipple, though I did not have any nipple changes.  This all happened the day before yesterday and I feel like I don't know what to do next.  I am in shock and have not even cried.  I am assuming that I am not going to be cured of this cancer, just maintained but I have no idea.  I get the results of the cores on Monday.  Does that result tell me what type of cancer I have and what stage?  I am in my 40s with 5 children.  I didn't even tell anyone about the lump because I didn't want to worry anyone if it turned out to be nothing. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2009 05:19PM seaofhope wrote: The doctor got the fine needle results because the center is located in a hospital and they must have a lab there.  Thank you everyone for the information.  I feel so much better now.
Posts.Title: When do I cry? seaofhope one-L

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2009 08:49PM seaofhope wrote: I am scheduled to see a surgeon in two weeks.  I could see one this week, but the one recommended to me is a two week wait.  My gyno said it won't matter since it is already in the lymph node and waiting one more week won't make much of a difference.  Getting the best surgeon with a great bedside matter is more important.  The only thing bothering me now is worrying that the different aches and pains that I ignored over the last year are really cancer that has matastisized.  On another note, I haven't had a glass of wine in a few weeks because I  wanted to keep my liver clean for all the tests.  But it is the holiday weekend - I guess one won't kill me!  Does anyone occasionally drink if they are going through tests?
Posts.Title: When do I cry? seaofhope one-L

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2009 01:43PM seaofhope wrote: I just took a shower and found another big lump in the depth of my armpit - that hard to shave part.  I feel like shouting the f-bomb a thousand times out on this board.  Still no tears - lots of anger.
Posts.Title: When do I cry? seaofhope one-L

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2009 12:08PM seaofhope wrote: njdarcy - I was given a list of questions to ask.  It is extensive but pick and choose which questions are relevent to you.  I plan on bringing a notebook to my appointment next week: 1. What type of cancer?  How does this affect treatment options and prognosis? 2.  Has my cancer spread to the lymph nodes? 3. What stage is it, and what is the treatment and prognosis? 4. Are any tests needed before treatment? 5. Should I enroll in a clinical trial? 6. What are the side effects and risks of the treatment?  7. How long will the treatment last?   8. Will it be by mouth or I.V? Where will I do it? 9. What should I be doing to get ready? (diet, juicing, etc) 10. Should I donate blood for a blood transfusion? 11. How effective is reconstructive surgery? 12. Pros and cons of doing reconstructive surgery immediately or waiting. 13. What will reconstructive surgery feel like?  14. What lifestyle changes should I make? 15. What are the chances of the cancer coming back?  What will we do if it does? 16. Will I go into menopause as a result of all this? 17.  How will I follow-up? Good luck!
Posts.Title: I am done angie27 Maire67

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2010 09:54AM seaofhope wrote: The pattern I see is that it is mostly estrogen positive women who recur 5 to 10 years later, even if they had no lymph node involvement.  I wonder if they had vascular invasion at the time.
Posts.Title: did all of u had pet/ct/bone scan the first time? melania lmc1970

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2009 10:29AM seaofhope wrote: They are more than happy to comply but may need advance notice.  Tell them in the morning that you are stopping by in the afternoon.  If they say they need more time, explain why it is convenient for you at the time you are coming.  They may move your charts ahead of the line.  Be firm but nice and you should have no problem.
Posts.Title: Getting a copy of your path report tovahsmom mawhinney

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2009 08:06PM seaofhope wrote: I had a fine needle biopsy and didn't even feel it - it's like getting a shot of novacaine. It took very little time.  The stereo core biopsies were more intense, though very little pain, just took a long time and were uncomfortable because of the way you have to position yourself on the table.  I think you should take anti-anxiety medicine to calm yourself down, and you will do fine.  The nurses will hold your hand and help you through this.  I didn't have time to stress since they did my biopsies right after my mammogram - waiting is what freaks us out!
Posts.Title: Biopsy BabyLemp1 allvirgo71

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2009 07:58PM seaofhope wrote: I had a couple of nodes positive also.  One was almost 3 cm. - deep in my armpit, the part that is hard to shave!  It was extracapsular by 2mm.  I wish I knew what this means as far as spreading to other parts of my body.  I asked the oncologist but she doesn't give me any answers, just says "this is why we are treating you with chemo and radiation".  I guess she doesn't have a crystal ball either.  Does anyone know how big lymph nodes are?  What about vascular invasion?  There isn't a lot of information out there.
Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2009 05:46PM seaofhope wrote: I too had a full blown panic attack with my first MRI.  I think part of the reason was because of all the stress of the diagnosis finally hitting me.  I started hyperventilating and sweating bullets.  One of the technicians stayed at the head of the opening and held my hands the whole time - what an angel she was.  I stayed in because I knew I would have to do it again anyway if I wimped out.  The next time I had a test I had my doctor prescribe anti-anxiety medicine.  I also took my mom's advice and closed my eyes before I went in the machine and never opened them.  They also spoke to me and told me how much time I had left.
Posts.Title: CHICKEND OUT ON MRI gegfl SuziQ422

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2009 09:27PM seaofhope wrote: I also looked for a date on these statistics and was relieved to see it was 20 years old.  Whew!
